bibl.title: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, May 24, 1921

div1.p: Connor comments on Hanson's and Pareja's work in Peru. He also discusses issues related to yellow fever work in Mexico.

div1.head: Letter from Michael E. Connor to Henry Rose Carter, May 24, 1921
div1.opener:

ESTADOS UNIDOS MEXACANOS

DE

JEFATURA DE LA CAMPAÑ CONTRA
LA FIEBRE AMARILLA EN YUCATAN.

MERIDA, YUC., MEX.
R
Connor
Merida Yucatan Mexico.
May 24, 1921.
My dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your welcome letter of May 3rd. to hand.
I am indeed glad to know that Dr. Hanson will be able to give all
his time to the problem. It was on this point that I had some
fears when the outbreak was first announced and that you were coming
home. Until your letter arrived I had been encouraging Dr. Rose to send
some one down to work with Hanson. But now he will be able to train local
men and to supervise their work with a frequency that will allow
progress to be made.

On the last mail I received a letter from
Dr. Pareja regarding his Bubonic problem. It seems to be upper-
most in his mind. In reply I took advantage of the opportunity to
encourage him once more to keep up his anti-larvae measures and I
am hoping that he will do so. On the same mail there was a letter
from Dr. Goding telling of your visit to him and he also mention-
ed that Pareja was working hard and is making a good impression.

Enclosed you will find a copy of Dr.
Villamil's artcile on yellow fever in which is mentioned the
probable presence of yellow fever amongst the-older Mayan peoples.
These references have been taken from the same source as those used
by the Bishop Ancoa-Carrillo and they are said to be authentic.

In Yucatan at the present moment there is a
representative of the American Museum of Natural History, Dr. Spinden,
and he is studying the ancient mayan civilization. I have discussed the
matter of translation of the passages of the Codices Tizimin and he
in turn submitted the question to Mr. Martinez, here in Merida, and
an authority on Mayan History. Mr. Martinez says that the translation is
in the main correct. He went on to state that the word translated from
Mayan and used in English a BLACK should really read BLOOD in other words
the Mayans did not used the equivilent of Black Vomit but BLOOD VOMIT.

To support your thought that yellow fever is of middle central american
origin Dr. Spinden tells me that in his opinion there must have been
a population of not less than 10,000,000 persons in the Peninsula and
part of Guatamala. He has just returned from Quintana Roo and found
there ruins larger than anything heretofore discovered in the Americas
and he goes on to tell how these people secured their water from
underground rivers which opened onto the surface at places and are
called zenotes. This practice indicates quite clearly that the people
were forced to conserve their home supply in conatiners which would
make possible a large stegomyia population.

PODER EJECUTIVO FEDERAL
ESTADOS UNIDOS MEXICANOS
MEXICO
DEPARTAMENTO
DE
SALUBRIDAD PUBLICA DE MEXICO.
____
JEFATURA DE LA CAMPAÑ CONTRA
LA FIEBRE AMARILLA EN YUCATAN.
____
MERIDA, YUC., MEX.

Dr. Spinden is interested in the subject which we
have been discussing for the reason that it may throw
some light on the riddle of the disappearnce of the
old Mayan civilization, and I have taken the liberty to
suggest to him that on his return to Washington to con-
sult you and he has made a note of your address.

Chalmers and Castellani mention the fact that the
first yellow fever to be reported from Mexico was in
1509 and occured at Vera Cruz. They do not give their
references for this statement. Do you regard this
as true?

A recent cable note states that Santa Tomas Hospital in Panama
is to form the nucleus of the Gorgas Memorial Institute in which
Tropical diseases will be studied and that the Rockefell Foundation
would give encouragement. I am glad that there is to be this
memorial to the General and wish for it every measure of success,
but the thought keeps coming up as to whether Panama is the
place to study tropical diseases. Would it not be wise to in-
clude in the program the taking over of the sanitation of the
cities of Panama and Colon and there to put in practice the
prinicipals of co-operation in the prevention of diseases?

During your time in Panama we were formulating a plan with this
in view, but somehow it was lost in the strife that followed.
On my recents visits to the Isthmus I could not help but be im-
pressed with the wonderful opportunity that presents itself and
how the present administration is letting it slip by. Their
thought seems to be that by placing a large enough fine on the
ignorant people that the principals of hygiene can be driven
home and made effective.

Under an organization that understands co-operation and has had
experience in placing the principals before the people in
such a manner that they can grasp the import, there can be built
up a workable plan that all Latin America will be glad to
adopt. The Government of Panama undoubtedly would be pleased to
enter into such an arrangement.

There could be started in the schools, from the first grade on,
a course in hygiene, elementary biology etc., that would be models
for all other schools.

You will be glad to know that our road here is opening up
with increasing clearness and that the public are responding to
the work with a spirit of goodwill which at first I did not ex-
pect to find as judged from the stories we heard before coming
here. They like the fish and really the fish helps to make
their stored cistern water more palatable and for this alone
they are pleased.
